tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Granet emerged from the Tregarten Hotel at St. Mary's on the following morning, about half-past eight, and strolled down the narrow strip of lawn which bordered the village street. A couple of boatmen advanced at once to meet him. Granet greeted them cheerily.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Yes, I want a boat," he admitted. "I'd like to do a bit of sailing. A friend of mine was here and had a chap named Rowsell--Job Rowsell. Either of you answer to that name, by chance?"

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The elder of the two shook his head.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "My name's Matthew Nichols," he announced, "and this is my brother-in-law, Joe Lethbridge. We've both of us got stout sailing craft and all the recommendations a man need have. As for Job Rowsell, well, he ain't here--not just at this moment, so to speak."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Granet considered the matter briefly.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Well," he decided, "it seems to me I must talk to this chap Rowsell before I do anything. I'm under a sort of promise."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The two boatmen looked at one another. The one who had addressed him first turned a little away.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Just as you like, sir," he announced. "No doubt Rowsell will be up this way towards afternoon."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Afternoon? But I want to go out at once," Granet protested.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Matthew Nichols removed his pipe from his mouth and spat upon the ground thoughtfully.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "I doubt whether you'll get Job Rowsell to shift before mid-day. I'm none so sure he'll go out at all with this nor-wester blowing."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "What's the matter with him?" Granet asked. "Is he lazy?"

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The man who as yet had scarcely spoken, swung round on his heel.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "He's no lazy, sir," he said. "That's not the right word. But he's come into money some way or other, Job Rowsell has. There's none of us knows how, and it ain't our business, but he spends most of his time in the public-house and he seems to have taken a fancy for night sailing alone, which to my mind, and there are others of us as say the same, ain't none too healthy an occupation. And that's all there is to be said of Job Rowsell, as I knows of."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "It's a good deal, too," Granet remarked thoughtfully. "Where does he live?"

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Fourth house on the left in yonder street," Matthew Nichols replied, pointing with his pipe. "Maybe he'll come if you send for him, maybe he won't."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "I must try to keep my word to my friend," Granet decided. "If I don't find him, I'll come back and look for you fellows again."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: He turned back to the little writing-room, scribbled a note and sent it down by the boots. In about half an hour he was called once more out into the garden. A huge, loose-jointed man was standing there, unshaven, untidily dressed, and with the look in his eyes of a man who has been drinking heavily.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Are you Job Rowsell?" Granet inquired.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "That's my name," the man admitted. "Is there anything wrong with it?"

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Not that I know of," Granet replied. "I want you to take me out sailing. Is your boat ready?"

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The man glanced up at the sky.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "I don't know as I want to go," he grumbled. "There's dirty weather about."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "I think you'd better," Granet urged. "I'm not a bad payer and I can help with the boat. Let's go and look at her any way."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: They walked together down to the harbour. Granet said very little, his companion nothing at all. They stood on the jetty and gazed across to where the sailing boats were anchored.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "That's the Saucy Jane," Job Rowsell indicated, stretching out a forefinger.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Granet scrambled down into a small dinghy which was tied to the side of the stone wall.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "We'd better be getting on board," he suggested.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Rowsell stared at him for a moment but acquiesced. They pulled across and boarded the Saucy Jane. A boy whom they found on the deck took the boat back. Rowsell set his sails slowly but with precision. The moment he stepped on board he seemed to become an altered man.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Where might you be wanting to go?" he asked. "You'll need them oilskins, sure."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "I want to run out to the Bishop Lighthouse," Granet announced.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Rowsell shook his head.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: It's no sort of a day to face the Atlantic, sir," he declared. "We'll try a spin round St. Mary and White Island, if you like."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Granet fastened his oilskins and stooped for a moment to alter one of the sails.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Look here," he said, taking his seat at the tiller, "this is my show, Job Rowsell. There's a five pound note for you at the end of the day, if you go where I tell you and nowhere else."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: The man eyed him sullenly. A few minutes later they were rushing out of the harbour.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "It's a poor job, sailing a pleasure boat," he muttered. "Not many of us as wouldn't sell his soul for five pounds."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: They reached St. Agnes before they came round on the first tack. Then, with the spray beating in their faces, they swung around and made for the opening between the two islands. For a time the business of sailing kept them both occupied. In two hours' time they were standing out towards Bishop Lighthouse. Job Rowsell took a long breath and filled a pipe with tobacco. He was looking more himself now.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "I'll bring her round the point there," he said, "and we'll come up the Channel and home by Bryher."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "You'll do nothing of the sort," Granet ordered. "Keep her head out for the open sea till I tell you to swing round."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Rowsell looked at his passenger with troubled face.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Are you another of 'em?" he asked abruptly.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Don't you mind who I am," Granet answered. "I'm on a job I'm going to see through. If a fiver isn't enough for you, make it a tenner, but keep her going where I put her."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Rowsell obeyed but his face grew darker. He leaned towards his passenger.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "What's your game?" he demanded hoarsely. "There's some of them on the island'd have me by the throat if they only knew the things I could tell 'em. What's your game here, eh? Are you on the cross?"

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "I am not," Granet replied, "or I shouldn't have needed to bring you to sea. I know all about you, Job Rowsell. You're doing very well and you may do a bit better by and by. Now sit tight and keep a still tongue in your head."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: They were in a queer part of the broken, rocky island group. There was a great indenture in the rocks up which the sea came hissing; to the left, round the corner, the lighthouse. Granet drew what looked to be a large pocket-handkerchief from the inner pocket of his coat, pulled down their pennant with nimble fingers, tied on another and hauled it up. Job Rowsell stared at him.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "What's that?"

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "It's the German flag, you fool," Granet answered.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "I'll have none of that on my boat," the man declared surlily. "An odd fiver for a kindness--"

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Shut up!" Granet snapped, drawing his revolver from his pocket. "You run the boat and mind your own business, Rowsell. I'm not out here to be fooled with.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: . . .My God!"

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Almost at their side the periscope of a submarine had suddenly appeared. Slowly it rose to the surface. An officer in German naval uniform struggled up and called out. Granet spoke to him rapidly in German. Job Rowsell started at them both, then he drew a flask from his pocket and took a long pull. The submarine grew nearer and Granet tossed a small roll of paper across the chasm of waters. All that passed between the two men was to Job Rowsell unintelligible. The last few words, however, the German repeated in English.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "The Princess Hilda from Southampton, tomorrow at midnight," he repeated thoughtfully. "Well, it's a big business."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "It's worth it," Granet assured him. "They may call it a hospital ship but it isn't. I am convinced that the one man who is more dangerous to us than any other Englishman, will be on board."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "It shall then be done," the other promised. "So!"

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: He looked upward to the flag and saluted Granet. A great sea bore them a little apart. Granet pulled down the German flag, tied up a stone inside it and threw it into the next wave.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "You can take me back now," he told the boatman.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: They were four hours making the harbour. Three times they failed to get round the last point, met at each time by clouds of hissing spray. When at last they sailed in, there was a little crowd to watch them. Nichols and Lethbridge stood on one side with gloomy faces.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "It's a queer day for pleasure sailing," Nicholas remarked to Job Rowsell, as he came up the wet steps of the pier.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "It's all I want of it for a bit, any way," Rowsell muttered, pushing his way along the quay. "If there's any of you for a drink, I'm your man. What-ho, Nichols?--Lethbridge?"

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Lethbridge muttered something and turned away. Nichols, too, declined.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "I am not sure, Job Rowsell," the latter declared, "that I like your money nor the way you earn it."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Job Rowsell stopped for a minute. There was an ugly look in his sullen face.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "If you weren't my own bother-in-law, Matthew Nichols," he said, "I'd shove those words down your throat."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "And if you weren't my sister's husband," Nichols retorted, turning away, "I'd take a little trip over to Penzance and say a few words at the Police Station there."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Granet laughed good-humouredly.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "You fellows don't need to get bad-tempered with one another," he observed. "Look here, I shall have three days here. I'll take one of you each day--make a fair thing of it, eh? You to-morrow, Nichols, and you the next day Lethbridge. I'm not particular about the weather, as Job Rowsell can tell you, and I've sailed a boat since I was a boy. I'm no land-lubber, am I, Rowsell?"

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "No, you can sail the boat all right," Rowsell admitted, looking back over his shoulder. "You'd sail it into Hell itself, if one'd let you. Come on, you boys, if there's any one of you as fancies to drink. I'm wet to the skin."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Nichols' boat was duly prepared at nine o'clock on the following morning. Lethbridge shouted to him from the rails.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Gentleman's changed his mind, I reckon. He went off on the eight o'clock boat for Penzance."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: Nichols commenced stolidly to furl his sails again.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "It's my thinking Lethbridge," he said, as he clambered into the dinghy, "that there's things going on in this island which you and me don't understand. I'm for a few plain words with Job Rowsell, though he's my own sister's husband."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "Plain words is more than you'll get from Job," Lethbridge replied gloomily. "He slept last night on the floor at the 'Blue Crown,' and he's there this morning, clamouring for brandy and pawing the air. He's got the blue devils, that's what he's got."

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p span
content: "There's money," Nichols declared solemnly, "some money, that is, that does no one any good."
